File name must NOT be EMPTY, or load fail upon next preset load

JamesDSP Guide 

 Getting Started

 For old users: Delete old JamesDSP Presets
 Note that JamesDSP presets are not compatible across versions‚Äînew versions of jDSP will crash if they attempt to load an old preset. It is recommended to delete your old Presets folder before running a new jDSP version.
 

 Save a new preset (3-dot menu on upper right)

 Headset / Speaker / Bluetooth
 One of these appears at the top of the screen. This indicates the device for which you are adjusting settings. Tap the hamburger icon to the upper left to change between these.

 Master switch / Output control

 +Master switch
 The switch itself is the on-off switch of everything (when a Headset is connected (‚ÄúHeadset‚Äù), when the onboard speaker is in use (‚ÄúSpeaker‚Äù), or when using Bluetooth (‚ÄúBluetooth‚Äù), depending on which is shown at the top).

 +Limiter threshold
 This is an output limiter that tries to avoid clipping of output (caused by DSP that tries to make part or all of the audio louder than before, if the input is already near maximum). This should be set to -0.1, unless for some reason your audio is clipping before digital clipping, in which case you can set it to lower values.

 +Limiter release
 The Limiter is only as effective as the release time it is given. Short release times will lead to audible distortion of the limited sound, especially of low frequencies; a long release is usually preferred, but reduces the volume that can be achieved somewhat. If ‚Äúpumping‚Äù (ducking of limited sound and it coming back up over time) becomes objectionable, making the release longer OR shorter can make the effect less noticeable.

 +Post gain
 This acts as a digital volume knob for all effects, after all effects have been applied but before the sound reaches the limiter.
 
 *for old versions of jDSP, the Post gain really is after everything, including the limiter; this usually led to distorted sound when the post gain is set to any positive value. This has been fixed in the latest version.
 

 Dynamic Range Compressor

 +Enable Dynamic Range Compressor
 Enables / disables the dynamic range compressor, a automatic dynamic range flattener which able to flatten the signal spectral to reduce transient, it is like a drum volume reducer.
 +Max attack
 This adjusts how fast the Dynamic Range Compressor react
 +Max release
 This adjusts how slow the Dynamic Range Compressor performing gain decay
 +Aggressiveness
 This adjusts how strong the spectral flattenning gonna be
 

 Dynamic Bass Boost

 +Enable Dynamic Bass Boost
 This is the button to enable jDSP‚Äôs dynamic bass boost, which attempts to create a pleasing bass sound with various dynamic algorithms. If the results don‚Äôt satisfy, one can always adjust the bass using the equalizer, DDC or convolver üòä

 Max gain
 This adjusts the amount of the dynamic bass boost effects.
 

 Interpolating FIR Equalizer

 +Enable FIR equalizer
 Enables / disables the FIR equalizer. FIR stands for ‚ÄúFinite Impulse Response‚Äù.
 
 +Filter type
 Chooses between Minimum phase and Linear phase filtering. Minimum phase is the recommended filter type, as it minimizes latency (effectively zero, for any sensible filter shape) while the phase changes introduced are not usually noticeable (linear phase is useful in pre- / post-production of multitrack recordings, in cases where phase relationships between tracks need to be preserved. In realtime playback, however, linear phase EQ introduces latency at least half as long as the filter length.)
 
 +Select preset
 This switches between ‚ÄúFlat‚Äù and Custom, where Custom is whatever thing that‚Äôs not Flat that you‚Äôve drawn yourself. Choose Flat if you want to reset this filter.
 

 Arbitrary Response Equalizer

 If you familiar with EqualizerAPO, you may already know GraphicEq, you can go to config.txt inside EqualizerAPO installation directory, copy the corresponding GraphicEq: ... string and paste it into Arbitrary Response Equalizer, jDSP able to provide identical result that you get from EqualizerAPO.
 

 Convolver

 Select your impulse response file(.wav, .irs, .flac) to be convolved
It takes the signal characteristics of impulse response and apply to the incoming audio in real time.

 Impulse response optimization
 It tries to reduce the length of impulse response as much as possible, the whole point is to reduce latency as much as we can, possibly reduce power consumption.

 ViPER-DDC
 Main job of it is to perform parametric equalization on audio, but doing so require user to provide .ddc file that DDCToolbox generates, ViPER-DDC in jDSP is a generalized implementation of second order section filters, which is a little bit different than the implementation in Viper4Android(V4A), V4A support only Peaking parametric filter, the reason for that is V4A uses share coefficient property of Peaking filter, while jDSP do not have such assumption.

 
 Live programmable DSP

 This is a virtual machine that compile .eel code file as input and run the instructions, in simple word, it allow user to program their own audio effect.


 The number of supported operation is enormous, go check out the official page: github.com/james34602/EEL_VM

 The internal codebase is so huge, I have built-in some useful operations like Fourier transform, Polyphase filterbank, let's show off your creativity, Don't Be a Programmer, Be a Problem Solver!

 EEL is a C-liked language
 
 Oversampled Analog Modelling

 +Preamp

 Oversampled Analog Modelling is a aliasing-free even harmonic generator.

 
 Sound positioning

 +Soundstage widthness

 A multiband stereo wideness controller, you like wider sound? Narrower sound?

 +Enable Crossfeed

 Tick this option if you want some realistic surround effect!

 
 Reverberation

 +Select room type

 Add some spatialness into the audio
